patient_information: A 34-year-old male immigrant from northern Peru, living in Chile for the past 9 years. Cachectic, body weight 44 kg (BMI 17).
chief_complaint: 6-month history of severe chronic diarrhoea, colicky abdominal pain, and 20 kg weight loss.
history_of_present_illness: For more than 12 years, he has suffered from recurrent episodes of diarrhoea and abdominal cramps, with increased frequency in the past 2 years. His mother and one brother suffered from chronic abdominal symptoms of unknown origin, leading to wasting and subsequent death at ages 45 and 28, respectively.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Originates from northern Peru, a tropical region highly endemic for S. stercoralis and HTLV-1.
physical_exam: Cachectic with severe loss of muscle mass (body weight 44 kg, BMI 17). Slight pain on abdominal palpation. Liver and spleen not enlarged. No palpable lymphadenopathy and no peripheral oedema.
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results: WBC 11.7 (elevated), Platelets 644 (elevated), Haemoglobin 12.4 (low), Protein 4.9 (low), Albumin 2.2 (low), ESR 26 (elevated), HIV test negative. Abdominal CT scan and MRI were without pathological findings. Oesophagogastroduodenoscopy appeared macroscopically normal. Histology of a duodenal biopsy showed signs of chronic duodenitis and multiple elongated structures compatible with a helminth infection. Baermann testing of a fresh stool sample demonstrated a high load of rhabditiform larvae of S. stercoralis. Larvae were also present in respiratory secretions but not in urine. HTLV-1 co-infection was confirmed by serology.
differential_diagnosis: Strongyloides stercoralis, Capillaria philippinensis. In immunocompromised patients: Cryptosporidium species or Cystoisospora belli.
management_and_clinical_course: Hospitalized, stabilized with symptomatic treatment and parenteral nutrition. Oral treatment with ivermectin (200 μg/kg per day × 7 days) was initiated and repeated after 2 weeks. The patient recovered from diarrhoea and abdominal symptoms within weeks. Parasitological follow-up after 3 months was negative. He gained 13 kg and was without postprandial abdominal cramps for the first time in over 10 years. Family screening revealed asymptomatic S. stercoralis infection in his wife and one child; his wife also tested HTLV-1 positive.
disease_name_short: Strongyloides Hyperinfection Syndrome with HTLV-1 co-infection
